docs.lead_paragraph: An article on June 13 about how pharmacists, at the behest of insurance companies, sometimes substitute a less expensive drug for the one originally prescribed, omitted the context for a comment by Kevin Colgan, a spokesman for Merck-Medco Managed Care, who said: ''The patient is accepting a benefit from their employer, and if they would like no management of their benefit, or no restrictions, they can always pay for it themselves out of pocket.'' Mr. Colgan was referring to an employee's entire drug benefit package, not to an individual prescription.
docs.abstract: Correction of June 13 article about how pharmacists, at behest of insurance companies, sometimes substitute less expensive drug for one originally prescribed, regarding comment by spokesman for managed care company

docs.lead_paragraph: EUGENE GROSSMAN picked a good place to have a dizzy spell. The 74-year-old retiree was a volunteer in the gift shop at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, and when he felt ill one day in April he was put on a gurney and rolled from the gift shop to the hospital's emergency room, where he was told that he might need an invasive diagnostic test and possibly a pacemaker. But after a two-day hospitalization at North Shore, Mr. Grossman decided to seek a second opinion. When he saw the second cardiologist four days after first feeling ill, he was told he could have a heart attack at any minute and was sent immediately to St. Francis Hospital in Flower Hill for an emergency admission.

headline.main: Cutbacks by Oxford Unsettling to Clients

docs.abstract: Article on problems that elderly Long Island patients of Oxford Health Plans health maintenance organization are encountering; case of Eugene Grossman, 74, who needed invasive heart test and pacemaker, detailed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sgt. Mike Lewis of the Maryland State Police is a bull-necked, megaphone-voiced, highly caffeinated drug warrior who, on this shiny May morning outside of Annapolis, is conceding defeat. The drug war is over, the good guys have lost and he has been cast as a racist. ''This is the end, buddy,'' he says. ''I can read the writing on the wall.'' Lewis is driving his unmarked Crown Victoria down the fast lane of Route 50, looking for bad guys. The back of his neck is burnt by the sun, and he wears his hair flat and short under his regulation Stetson. ''They're going to let the N.A.A.C.P. tell us how to do traffic stops,'' he says. ''That's what's happening. There may be a few troopers who make stops solely based on race, but thisa they're going to let these people tell us how to run our department. I say, to hell with it all. I don't care if the drugs go through. I don't.''
docs.abstract: Jeffrey Goldberg article interviews a number of police officers, white and black, on the issue of racial profiling; they insist practice is rooted not in racism but in statistical reality, the fact that blacks commit a disproportionate precentage of the types of crimes that draw their attention, particularly drug trafficking; some allow that while blacks make up only 13 percent of country's illicit drug users, they make up 74 percent of people who are sentenced to prison for drug possession, largely because white community would never allow the police to treat it the way they treat the black community; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Do employers tilt the workplace toward workers who have children? In his column, ''In Defense of the Single and Childless'' (On the Contrary, June 6), Daniel Akst argued that they do -- whether by offering subsidized child care, pensions with survivors' benefits or health insurance for workers' dependents. The column drew varied responses. To the Editor: Congratulations to Dan Akst for discussing what much of the business world would rather leave unsaid: the expectation that single, childless workers will work harder than their married counterparts while receiving far less from their employers, particularly in benefits.

headline.main: Married, With Children: The Workplace Benefits

docs.abstract: Deborah Prigal letter comments on Daniel Akst's June 6 article on bias against single, childless persons in the workplace

headline.main: When More Medicine Saves Money; Don't Place Blame

docs.lead_paragraph: The Walt Disney Company's ABC Inc. unit and leaders of most of its unionized broadcast and engineering workers said yesterday that they had reached a tentative contract agreement. Five locals, representing more than 1,800 of the 2,400 members of the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians at ABC, agreed to the contracts after having rejected a settlement in February. At that time, seven other locals, representing about 600 workers, had ratified the settlement.

headline.main: ABC and Union Leaders in Tentative Pact

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re Mark Schiller's June 15 Op-Ed article against parity in mental health care coverage: The American Psychiatric Association has documented the high economic costs of untreated mental illness. According to the National Mental Health Advisory Council, parity for severe mental illness would save $2.2 billion a year. There are also studies showing that the likely effect of parity would be to increase typical plan premiums modestly, by 2.5 percent to 3.9 percent.
docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Anthony F Villamena disagrees with Mark Schiller's June 15 Op-Ed article against parity in mental health care coverage; says parity law for state employees in North Carolina shows this benefit does not increase total health care costs and may even reduce them

docs.lead_paragraph: On the second floor of a century-old brick theater building here, the staff at Chelsea Green Publishing has been puzzling over the phenomenon of ''The Straw Bale House.'' Five years ago, when Chelsea Green first published the guide for building a home out of straw bales, it expected to sell a few thousand copies. Now, even though there are only 1,000 or 2,000 such houses in the nation, sales are nearing 100,000.

headline.main: Living By the Books; Vermont Publisher Succeeds With Guides for a Simpler Life

docs.abstract: Chelsea Green Publishing, which since 1992 has focused on publishing books on living simpler life, has doubled sales since 1996, to more than $2 million; has gone from publishing four books in 1996 to current 26; success of its book, The Straw Bale House, discussed; founder Ian Baldwin comments; chart; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: More than two dozen municipal employees, including 15 school nurses, were arrested yesterday and charged with illegally collecting more than $70,000 in unemployment benefits over the last five years while working for New York City, authorities said. The 28 people arrested were seasonal employees, who worked in a variety of agencies, including the departments of parks, highways and public health. Most collected between $1,000 and $3,000 in benefits for which they were not eligible, officials said.

headline.main: City Employees Charged In Benefits Scheme

docs.abstract: Twenty-eight seasonal employees of New York City are arrested and charged with illegally collecting more than $70,000 in unemployment benefits over the last five years while for New York City; allegedly continued to claim they were on layoff after resuming work (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes a piece of legislation makes such obvious good sense that it commands support from all points on the political spectrum. That happened on Wednesday when the Senate voted 99 to 0 to pass the Work Incentives Improvement Act to allow disabled Americans to work without fear of losing health coverage under Medicare and Medicaid. The legislation would at last end the perverse financial disincentives in disability law that prevent people from becoming self-sufficient. More than 7.5 million disabled Americans receive Federal benefits through Social Security Disability Insurance and Supplemental Security Income. Many may want to work, but less than one-half of 1 percent receiving disability insurance do because they would lose their cash benefits if they earned more than $500 a month. Worse, they would lose their health coverage after three years. The new act -- sponsored by James Jeffords and William Roth, both Republicans, and the Democrats Edward Kennedy and Daniel Patrick Moynihan -- would allow the disabled to keep their Medicare benefits when they return to work, and also create a system under which cash benefits would gradually diminish as earnings rose.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Work Incentives Improvement Act just passed by 99-0 vote in Senate allows disabled Americans to work without fear of losing health coverage under Medicare and Medicaid; says bill makes such good sense that House should move quickly on legislation to give final passage to measure
